title: Killiane Castle or Killiane Castle House

def: Attached seven-bay three-storey over basement farmhouse, between 1707-60; extant 1766, originally seven-bay two-storey with dormer attic on a symmetrical T-shaped plan with single-bay (single-bay deep) full-height central return (south).  Modified, 1974/5, producing present composition [CEMA].  Now in use as guesthouse.  Replacement pitched slate roof, 1974/5, on a T-shaped plan with ridge tiles, grey brick Flemish bond chimney stacks having chevron- or saw tooth-profiled stringcourses below capping supporting pots, and aluminium rainwater goods on timber eaves.  Roughcast walls with inscribed rendered piers to ends rising to rendered stringcourse supporting cement rendered walls to top floor.  Square-headed window openings with cut-granite shallow sills, and rendered block-and-start surrounds centred on keystones framing four-over-four timber sash windows having part exposed sash boxes.  Square-headed door opening with limestone flagged threshold, and cut-granite Gibbsian doorcase centred on fluted keystone framing timber panelled door.  Interior including entrance hall-cum-staircase retaining staircase on a dog leg plan with turned timber balusters supporting carved timber banister terminating in volute; drawing room with Classical-style chimneypiece; timber surrounds to door openings to remainder framing timber panelled doors, timber panelled reveals or shutters to window openings, and "Cavetto" or run moulded plasterwork cornices to ceilings.  Set in own grounds with remains of semi-coursed random rubble stone curtain wall to perimeter of bawn [SS].APPRAISAL:A farmhouse of minor country house of the middle size widely regarded as a particularly important component of the eighteenth-century domestic built heritage of south County Wexford having been erected by Reverend James Harvey (1676-1760) not only abutting the ???? medieval Killiane Castle (extant 1543), '[a] strong castle…of comparative preservation' (Lacy 1852, 285), but also reputedly incorporating the fabric of the adjoining bawn wall with the architectural value of the composition, not only rooted firmly in the early Georgian tradition, but also '[presenting] the appearance of a house of long standing' (ibid., 285), established by such attributes as the symmetrical rectilinear plan form centred on a Gibbsian doorcase demonstrating good quality stone masonry, and the uniform, albeit somewhat slender proportions of the openings on each floor.  However, while the elementary form and massing largely prevail together with quantities of the original fabric, the substitution of the once remarkably high pitched "garretted" roofline has radically affected the external expression or integrity of the composition.  Nevertheless, a collection of adjacent outbuildings (extant 1840), and evidence of a nearby lime kiln (extant 1903), all continue to contribute positively to the group and setting values of an estate having historic connections with the Harvey family including Vigors Harvey (b. 1794), the Aylward, and the Cooper families.
Department of Environment, Heritage and Local Government.  All Rights Reserved.
Killiane Castle or Killiane Castle House
